thread.title: Huge 1st quarter helps NC State beat Wake Forest 35-17
thread.title_full: Huge 1st quarter helps NC State beat Wake Forest 35-17

title: Huge 1st quarter helps NC State beat Wake Forest 35-17
text:
Wake Forest's defense has big setback in disastrous 1st quarter of 35-17 loss to NC State By AARON BEARD AP Sports Writer  20  20   
People: 
North Carolina (541) 

WINSTON-SALEM, North Carolina — Defense has been one thing Wake Forest coach Dave Clawson could count on in the early stages of his ground-up program rebuilding job. 
That unit is suddenly struggling for stops. 
The Demon Deacons surrendered four touchdowns of at least 50 yards in the first quarter in Saturday's 35-17 loss to North Carolina State. It marked the second straight week that they struggled to match up against an instate league opponent, following last week's 50-14 loss at North Carolina. 
Wake Forest gave up seven plays of at least 20 yards that resulted in 291 yards in that one, according to STATS. And by the time N.C. State sprinted to a 28-0 lead, Wake Forest had given up a run of 56 unanswered points. 
"Right now," Clawson said, "we are a really poor tackling team against good people." 
Wake Forest had generally played tough — even against still-unbeaten Florida State — this season, and came into this one ranked near the middle of the Atlantic Coast Conference in total defense (330.6 yards) and scoring defense (21.7 points). 
But this one got away early. 
Matt Dayes ran for 205 yards and two long touchdowns to lead the Wolfpack (5-2, 1-2 ACC), who largely sleptwalk through the final three quarters against the Demon Deacons (3-5, 1-4). 
The opening burst was more than enough to end a six-game losing streak in Winston-Salem, a curious skid in which the Demon Deacons had frustrated eventual NFL quarterbacks Philip Rivers, Russell Wilson and Mike Glennon. N.C. State hadn't won here since 2001 when Rivers — now a 12-year NFL veteran with nearly 39,000 career passing yards — was a sophomore. 
Jacoby Brissett connected with Maurice Trowell for a 59-yard touchdown pass 53 seconds into the game, then followed Dayes' 85-yard TD run on the second series by hitting freshman Nyheim Hines deep down the left side for a 58-yard touchdown. By the time Dayes struck again from 57 yards out, North Carolina State had rolled to 322 yards in the opening quarter. 
It marked the first time a Bowl Subdivision team had scored four touchdowns of at least 50 yards in the same quarter since Toledo did it in the third quarter against Eastern Michigan in October 2012, according to STATS. 
About the only thing the Wolfpack accomplished the rest of the day was running out the clock. 
The offense never returned to the end zone as its output fell dramatically, while rookie Kyle Bambard missed a pair of short field goals. N.C. State finished with 153 yards over the last three quarters, with Brissett throwing for 173 of his 227 yards in the opening period. 
Freshman reserve quarterback Kendall Hinton scored on a 69-yard keeper late in the first half and added a second scoring run in the final minute for the Demon Deacons, who otherwise had to fight for just about every gain and surrendered seven sacks. 
The Wolfpack got a 52-yard punt return for a touchdown in the fourth quarter from Bra'Lon Cherry, but lost starting linebacker Jerod Fernandez late in the third when he was carted off with an apparent right leg injury after making a tackle. Doeren said X-rays revealed no fracture but the nature of the injury wasn't immediately clear. 
Follow Aaron Beard on Twitter at http://www.twitter.com/aaronbeardap and the AP's college football site at http://collegefootball.ap.org .
